Data are shown only in regions where more than 60% of models agree on the sign of regression. h Multi-model medians of the quasi-stationary Rossby wave train index, defined as the mean 200 hPa GPH anomaly over the regions marked in (g), comparing historical and SSP585 periods.Full size imageIn summary, the Atlantic Ocean contributes to WNPAC intensification across all seasons through distinct mechanisms: strengthened equatorial waves and quasi-stationary Rossby wave trains in winter, a more pronounced quasi-stationary Rossby wave train in spring, and intensified equatorial Rossby wave dynamics in summer.Dominant role of the tropical Pacific in summer WNPAC intensificationThe tropical Pacific Ocean’s contribution to WNPAC increases significantly in summer. To assess this enhanced role under global warming, we also examine the changes of Pacific-driven WNPAC activity and identify the underlying mechanisms (Fig. 6 and Supplementary Fig. 7). The Pacific index (CEP) is defined using DJF SST anomalies to reflect the mature ENSO signal, consistent with its lagged influence on WNPAC confirmed by lead–lag correlations (Supplementary Fig. 4d–f).Fig. 6: The Pacific Ocean’s influence on intensified WNPAC.a–f MME regression patterns of precipitation (shading; units: mm day⁻¹), 850 hPa horizontal winds (vectors; units: m s⁻¹), and SLP (contours; units: hPa) onto CEP index during a, b winter, c, d spring, and e, f summer. a, c, e Historical forcing (1900–2014). b, d, f Future changes (SSP585 minus historical; 2015–2099). Data are shown only in regions where more than 60% of models agree on the sign of regression. g Multi-model medians of the Rossby wave index, defined as the area-averaged negative precipitation anomalies over the tropical western Pacific (5°–25°N, 130°E–180°E; blue box in (a)), for historical and SSP585 periods. h Multi-model medians of Easterly Wind Index, calculated as the area-averaged negative zonal wind anomaly over the western Pacific (0°–15°N, 120°E–160°E; red box in (a)).Full size imageThe ENSO-related WNPAC intensifies markedly during the decaying summer, as evidenced by significantly intensified SLP anomalies and anticyclonic wind circulation over the WNP region (Fig. 6f). In contrast, no substantial intensification rate is observed in winter and spring (Fig. 6b, d).The influence of the tropical Pacific primarily operates through two mechanisms: WES feedback triggered by El Niño10,11,14 and the Rossby wave induced by central Pacific cooling7,24,32. Under global warming, although CEP warming intensifies when WNPAC occurs in both winter and spring (Fig. 2c, f), the resultant cyclonic Rossby waves—particularly northeasterly wind anomalies over the central Pacific—remain weakly amplified (Fig. 6b, d). These weak amplified anomalies fail to significantly enhance the background trade winds or introduce negative moist enthalpy, leading to only marginal suppression of convection and minimal WNPAC intensification. Quantified via precipitation anomalies over the WNP (Fig. 6g), the Rossby wave effect shows limited enhancement in winter and spring.In contrast, during the summer of ENSO decay phases, CEP warming weakens while cooling over the central-western Pacific strengthens (Fig. 2g, h). This cooling intensifies under global warming (Fig. 2i), further suppressing convection and reinforcing WNPAC via enhanced Rossby wave activity (Fig. 6f). The quantified Rossby wave index increases by 90.7% in summer (JJA), which is notably higher than in winter (DJF, 36.5%) and spring (MAM, 24.0%), although its overall magnitude remains moderate (Fig. 6g).Simultaneously, enhanced warming over the Indo-Pacific warm pool and cooling over the central-western Pacific (CWP) establish a robust SST gradient (Fig. 2g, h), which induces easterly anomalies over the WNP region (Fig. 6e and Supplementary Fig. 7c). These easterlies maintain WNPAC via Ekman pumping-induced boundary layer divergence24,25,40. Under global warming, these easterlies strengthen notably in summer (Fig. 6f), quantified by zonal wind anomalies over the tropical western Pacific (Fig. 6h). The increase in easterly winds (Fig. 6f, h) is more significant than the enhancement in Rossby wave activity (Fig. 6f, g), suggesting that the SST gradient–induced easterlies constitute the primary mechanism behind the enhanced Pacific contribution to intensified WNPAC in summer.Consequently, the Pacific’s contribution to WNPAC intensification peaks during El Niño decay summers, driven predominantly by stronger easterlies associated with enhanced SST gradients between the Indo-Pacific warm pool and the central-western Pacific, and to a lesser extent by increased Rossby wave activity linked to central-eastern Pacific cooling.Modest tropical Indian’s effect on WNPACThe tropical Indian Ocean exhibits a comparatively limited increase in its contribution to WNPAC across all three seasons and exerts its greatest influence during the concurrent season (Supplementary Fig. 4d–f). During the decay phase of El Niño in spring and summer, TIO warming triggers anomalous easterlies over the western WNP through two primary mechanisms: equatorial eastward-propagating Kelvin waves26,27 and the Indian Ocean-Western Pacific SST gradient7,24,25. Both processes support WNPAC maintenance by suppressing convection via Ekman pumping (Supplementary Fig. 8). Projections indicate that these easterly anomalies intensify during spring and summer under global warming conditions (Fig. 7c, d), although their strength increase remains significantly weaker than the influences from the Pacific (Fig. 6h). The relatively weak WNPAC intensification associated with the Indian Ocean (Fig. 7a–c) can be attributed to limited warming over the northern Indian Ocean (Fig. 2f, i), where SST trends are neutral or even negative under global warming, and to a suppressed convective response likely caused by increased atmospheric stability under global warming35,40,48 (Fig. 7a–c).Fig. 7: The Indian Ocean’s ENSO-independent influence on intensified WNPAC.a–c Differences in MME partial regression patterns of precipitation (shading; units: mm day⁻¹), 850 hPa horizontal winds (vectors; units: m s⁻¹) and SLP (contour; units: hPa) onto the TIO index under SSP585 forcing relative to historical forcing, after removing ENSO effects, during a winter, b spring, and c summer. Data are shown only in regions where more than 60% of models agree on the sign of regression. d Multi-model medians of the Easterly Wind Index.Full size imageDiscussionOur study reveals that WNPAC intensifies across winter, spring, and summer under global warming. Building on prior studies that largely focused on summer or on individual basins, this work provides a systematic and quantitative inter-basin comparison of WNPAC across key seasons, offering an integrated framework to evaluate the relative contributions of the Pacific, Atlantic, and Indian Oceans. Through explained variance analysis with seasonally aligned assessments, we quantify both the relative importance and distinct pathways of the three tropical oceans. The results underscore the dominant roles of the Atlantic and Pacific in intensifying WNPAC under global warming, with the Atlantic exhibiting the most pronounced increase in influence and the Pacific exerting its strongest impact during summer, whereas the Indian Ocean’s contribution remains comparatively modest.To assess how these amplified oceanic contributions drive the intensification of WNPAC, we analyze the underlying mechanistic linkages (Fig. 8). The results indicate that TNA warming primarily intensifies WNPAC through equatorial wave responses and quasi-stationary Rossby wave trains during winter. In spring, the influence of equatorial waves weakens, and upper-tropospheric quasi-stationary Rossby wave trains become a dominant mechanism. During summer, the intensification is mainly attributed to equatorial Rossby wave dynamics. The Pacific Ocean contributes to summer WNPAC intensification primarily through anomalous easterlies over the WNP, induced by the enhanced SST gradient between the Indo-Pacific warm pool and the central-western Pacific. A secondary contribution arises from Rossby waves triggered by cooling in the central Pacific. In contrast, the Indian Ocean exerts a moderate and relatively consistent influence across all three seasons. Collectively, these findings highlight the seasonally distinct yet increasingly important roles of the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans in modulating WNPAC intensification under future warming scenarios.Fig. 8: Schematic representation of the mechanisms contributing to intensified WNPAC.a In winter, enhanced TNA warming intensifies WNPAC through three pathways: (1) triggering westward-propagating Rossby waves that reach the WNP region, reinforcing trade winds and promoting surface cooling; (2) generating eastward-propagating Kelvin waves that reach the western Pacific; and (3) enhancing convection over the tropical North Atlantic, which excites quasi-stationary Rossby wave trains in the upper troposphere extending toward WNP. b In spring, intensified TNA warming contributes to WNPAC strengthening primarily through quasi-stationary Rossby wave trains in the upper troposphere, and the influence of equatorial wave processes weakens. c In summer, the combined effects of enhanced TNA warming and the central Pacific cooling intensify WNPAC via equatorial Rossby wave dynamics and the strengthening of easterlies over the tropical western Pacific, driven by the enhanced SST gradient between the Indo-Pacific warm pool and the central-western Pacific.Full size imageTropical ocean basins are physically interconnected through large-scale atmospheric circulation, and such inter-basin interactions—via the Walker circulation or subtropical teleconnections—can modulate WNPAC response. To assess whether these interactions bias our attribution, we conducted sensitivity tests by additionally removing SST anomalies from the other two basins when isolating each ocean’s effect. While this may dampen some coupled signals, the influential patterns remained largely consistent. This suggests that although inter-basin coupling exists and may modulate the total response, the dominant pathways and relative contributions of each ocean remain physically robust and are not artifacts of the regression setup.Our study suggests that warming over the Indian Ocean contributes only modestly to the intensification of WNPAC. Although partial regression patterns reveal a relatively intensified WNPAC and anomalous easterlies in summer (Fig. 7c) under intensified TIO warming (Fig. 2i), the response appears to be primarily driven by suppressed convection over the western Pacific, as well as the weak convection response in the northern Indian Ocean. This is consistent with He et al.40, who also emphasized the importance of the zonal SST gradient between the TIO and Pacific, but highlighted that the gradient becomes increasingly shaped by stronger and more consistent Pacific SST cooling under warming scenarios. Furthermore, both studies identify a weakened sensitivity of WNPAC to TIO SST anomalies, largely due to enhanced atmospheric stability and shallower vertical motion over TIO35,40,48, which suppresses the generation of warm Kelvin waves. This weakened response not only reduces the direct impact of TIO warming but also limits the TIO’s contribution to strengthening the zonal SST gradient, ultimately leading to a lower relative contribution from the Indian Ocean to WNPAC intensification under global warming. These findings highlight the need for further quantitative investigation into the Indian Ocean’s independent mechanistic role under global warming, particularly its coupling with regional atmospheric dynamics.MethodsReanalysis and CMIP6 dataIn this study, monthly SST data are sourced from the Extended Reconstructed Sea Surface Temperature version 5 (ERSSTv5)49 at a horizontal resolution of \(2^\circ \,\times \,2^\circ\). Monthly sea level pressure (SLP) data are obtained from the European Center for Medium-Range Weather Forecasting Reanalysis version 5 (ERA5)50 at a spatial resolution of 0.25° × 0.25°.To estimate the future changes in WNPAC, monthly outputs from 43 CMIP6 models are analyzed for the period 1900-2099 (Supplementary Table 1). The historical simulations up to 2014 are conducted under historical scenario forcing, followed by future projections under the Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5–8.5 (SSP585) high-emission scenario, representing a warming climate. To ensure consistency, monthly anomaly variables—including SLP, precipitation (Precip), geopotential height (GPH), SST, tropospheric temperature (TT), and vertical (W) and horizontal (U, V) winds—are derived by referencing the climatological mean of 1900–1999, with the linear trend removed. All variables are regridded to a 1° × 1° resolution. Seasonal data are obtained by averaging the monthly values for boreal winter (December–February, DJF), spring (March–May, MAM), and summer (June–August, JJA). Changes in WNPAC are evaluated by comparing the period 1900–2014, which represents the historical state, and 2015–2099, which represents the future state. Additionally, a comparison between 1900–1999 and 2000-2099 is conducted; however, the key findings of this study remain unchanged (not shown).Definition of indicesTo quantify the intensity of WNPAC, we compute the WNPAC index as SLP anomalies over the WNP region (10° N–30° N, 120° E–160° E)22,51. Building upon prior research19,52, SST indices for the three tropical oceans are established based on the regions exerting the greatest impact on WNPAC: CEP (10° S–10° N, 180°–90° W) for the Pacific Ocean, TIO (20° S–20° N, 40° E–100° E) for the Indian Ocean and TNA (0°–20° N, 80° W–20° W) for the Atlantic Ocean (Supplementary Fig. 1). SST anomalies exert seasonally varying influences on WNPAC, with peak impacts observed for winter SST anomalies in the CEP region in winter and subsequent spring/summer WNPAC variability, and spring/summer SST anomalies in the TIO and TNA regions on simultaneous-season WNPAC dynamics (Supplementary Fig. 4d–f). All regressed indices are standardized to enhance comparability and stability by eliminating unit dependence.Furthermore, the variability of WNPAC and the three oceans’ indices is quantified using a 31-year moving standard deviation of each index. The frequency of WNPAC events is defined as the number of occurrences where the WNPAC index exceeds 0.75 standard deviations within the running window, while its amplitude is derived from the mean WNPAC index of these events53.To quantify the intensity of processes by which three tropical oceans contribute to WNPAC, indices for equatorial waves and the quasi-stationary Rossby wave train are defined. The intensity of the equatorial Rossby wave is measured by the magnitude of the negative area-averaged precipitation anomaly over the tropical western Pacific (5°N–25°N, 130°E–180°E), where a stronger negative anomaly reflects enhanced anticyclonic Rossby wave activity contributing to WNPAC. Kelvin wave index is defined as the magnitude of the negative (easterly) mean zonal wind anomaly over the equatorial western Pacific (0°–5°N, 120°E–160°E). Similarly, the strength of anomalous easterlies over the WNP region is measured by the magnitude of the negative mean zonal wind anomaly over the western Pacific (0°–15°N, 120°E–160°E). The intensity of the quasi-stationary Rossby wave train, which is triggered by tropical North Atlantic warming and propagates to the WNP, is quantified by the 200 hPa GPH anomalies over key circulation anomaly regions along the wave path (as shown in Fig. 5g), defining as: -GPH(30°N–45°N,80°W–30°W) + GPH(50°N–65°N,60°W–10°W) -GPH(45°N–60°N,10°E–60°E) + GPH(40°N–55°N,70°E–120°E) -GPH(25°N–40°N,110°E–160°E).Bootstrap estimation of inter-model uncertaintyTo estimate the inter-model spread of the multi-model ensemble for each year, we apply a bootstrap resampling procedure to the annual ensemble of model mean54. For each year, 10,000 bootstrap samples are generated by resampling 43 model ensembles with replacement. The standard deviation is computed for each resample, and the mean of the 10,000 standard deviations is used as the uncertainty estimate for that year. This approach provides a robust estimate of ensemble variability and is used to construct the uncertainty shading in Fig. 1.Contribution indices of three tropical oceans to WNPACThe relative contributions of the three tropical oceans to WNPAC are assessed via the explained variance (EV) of regions exerting the strongest influence on WNPAC, identical to those used in calculating the three oceans’ SST indices. The explained variance is determined as the regional mean of squared correlation coefficients between the SST anomalies and WNPAC index, formulated as:$$\begin{array}{c}{EV}=\frac{1}{N}{\sum }_{i=1}^{N}\left({r}_{i}^{2}\right)\end{array}$$
                    (1)
                Here, \({EV}\) represents the explained variance, \(N\) denotes the number of grid points in the defined region, \({r}_{i}\) is the Pearson correlation coefficient between SST anomalies and WNPAC index at grid point \(i\), and R-square represents the coefficient of determination. This metric quantifies the proportion of WNPAC variability attributable to SST variations at each grid point.The Pearson correlation coefficient \({r}_{i}\) at grid point \(i\) is calculated as:$$\begin{array}{c}{r}_{i}=\frac{{\sum }_{t=1}^{T}\left({SS}{T}_{i,t}-\overline{{SS}{T}_{i}}\right)\left({WNPA}{C}_{t}-\overline{{WNPAC}}\right)}{\sqrt{{\sum }_{t=1}^{T}{\left({SS}{T}_{i,t}-\overline{{SS}{T}_{i}}\right)}^{2}}\sqrt{{\sum }_{t=1}^{T}{\left({WNPA}{C}_{t}-\overline{{WNPAC}}\right)}^{2}}}\end{array}$$
                    (2)
                where \({SS}{T}_{i,t}\) represents the SST at grid point \(i\) and time \(t\), \(\overline{{SS}{T}_{i}}\) is the climatological mean SST at grid point \(i\), \({WNPA}{C}_{t}\) denotes WNPAC index at time \(t\), \(\overline{{WNPAC}}\) is the climatological mean of WNPAC index, and \(T\) corresponds to the total number of temporal observations. These formulas establish a robust statistical framework to quantify the contributions of SST variability across the three ocean basins to WNPAC dynamics, enabling a comparative evaluation of their relative influences. The rate of increase in explained variance is calculated as the percentage rise under future forcing relative to historical forcing.Liang–Kleeman information flowThe Liang–Kleeman information flow framework is an information-theoretic approach that measures the causal influence between two time series43,44. Unlike correlation, which is symmetric, information flow is directional, thereby allowing identification of driver–response relationships. The directionality and strength of causality from SST (X₂) to WNPAC (X₁) is estimated under a linear model as:$${T}_{2\to 1}=\frac{{C}_{11}{C}_{12}{C}_{2,{\rm{d}}1}-{C}_{12}^{2}{C}_{1,{\rm{d}}1}}{{C}_{11}^{2}{C}_{22}-{C}_{11}{C}_{12}^{2}}$$
                    (3)
                where\(\,{C}_{{ij}}\) is the sample covariance between \({X}_{i}\) and \({X}_{j}\), and \({C}_{i,{dj}}\) is the covariance between \({X}_{i}\) and the time derivative of \({X}_{j}\). A significant positive \({T}_{2\to 1}\) indicates a causal influence from SST to WNPAC.Lead–lag correlation analysisLead–lag correlation analysis was conducted between the dominant SST modes of the tropical Pacific, Indian, and Atlantic Oceans and WNPAC index. Correlation coefficients were calculated with SST anomalies leading or lagging the WNPAC index by up to 9 months. This approach identifies the season of peak influence for each basin on WNPAC variability and provides the physical basis for the seasonal pairing adopted in the EV and regression analyses.Wave activity flux (WAF) calculationThe WAF shown in Fig. 5 is calculated based on the formula of Takaya and Nakamura55, which diagnoses the horizontal propagation of quasi-stationary Rossby waves. The WAF is computed at 200 hPa using monthly mean fields of zonal wind u, meridional wind v, and geopotential height \(\Phi\) from the CMIP6 model outputs. Eddy components are defined as deviations from the zonal mean.The horizontal components of the WAF vector are given by:$$\begin{array}{lll}\vec{{W}_{h}}&=&\frac{pcos\varphi }{2\left|\vec{{U}_{c}}\right|}\left(\frac{{U}_{c}}{{a}^{2}{\cos }^{2}\varphi }\right.\left[{\left(\frac{\partial {\psi }^{{\prime} }}{\partial \lambda }\right)}^{2}-{\psi }^{{\prime} }\frac{{\partial }^{2}{\psi }^{{\prime} }}{\partial {\lambda }^{2}}\right]\\&&+\,\frac{{V}_{c}}{{a}^{2}\cos \varphi }\left[\frac{\partial {\psi }^{{\prime} }}{\partial \lambda }\frac{\partial {\psi }^{{\prime} }}{\partial \varphi }-{\psi }^{{\prime} }\frac{{\partial }^{2}{\psi }^{{\prime} }}{\partial \lambda \partial \varphi }\right]\frac{{U}_{c}}{{a}^{2}\cos \varphi }\left[\frac{\partial {\psi }^{{\prime} }}{\partial \lambda }\frac{\partial {\psi }^{{\prime} }}{\partial \varphi }-{\psi }^{{\prime} }\frac{{\partial }^{2}{\psi }^{{\prime} }}{\partial \lambda \partial \varphi }\right]\\&&+\,\left.\frac{{V}_{c}}{{a}^{2}}\left[{\left(\frac{\partial {\psi }^{{\prime} }}{\partial \varphi }\right)}^{2}-{\psi }^{{\prime} }\frac{{\partial }^{2}{\psi }^{{\prime} }}{\partial {\varphi }^{2}}\right]\right)\end{array}$$
                    (4)
                where \(\psi {\prime}\) is the perturbation stream function, derived from the ratio of geopotential anomaly \(\Phi {\rm{\mbox{'}}}\) to the planetary vorticity \(f\), \({U}_{c}\) and \({V}_{c}\) are the climatological zonal and meridional winds, \(a\) is the Earth’s radius, \(\lambda\) and \(\varphi\) are longitude and latitude, and \(p\) is the normalized atmospheric pressure. This formula allows visualization of wave energy propagation associated with anomalous circulation.Partial regression analysisThe partial regression model is a statistical method used to isolate the relationship between independent and dependent variables by removing the influence of a control variable56. In this study, signals from other ocean basins may obscure the individual effects of the target basin. To disentangle these influences, a partial linear regression analysis is applied:$$\begin{array}{c}Y=\alpha \times {I}_{A}+r.{Y}_{-A}\end{array}$$
                    (5)
                $$\begin{array}{c}r.{Y}_{-A}=\gamma \times {\rm{I}}+r.{Y}_{-I-A}\end{array}$$
                    (6)
                Here, \(Y\) denotes the target climate variable (e.g., precipitation, SLP, SST), \(I\) represents the SST indices of the target oceans (CEP, TIO, TNA indices), and \({I}_{A}\) represents the controlling NINO3.4 index to be removed. Equation (5) removes the direct influence of \({I}_{A}\) from \(Y\), yielding the residual \(r.{Y}_{-A}\); and Eq. (6) regresses \(r.{Y}_{-A}\) onto \(I\), thus quantifying the independent relationship between \(Y\) and \(I\) after removing the effect of ENSO. The coefficients \({\rm{\alpha }}\) quantify the direct influence of ENSO, while \({\rm{\gamma }}\) characterizes the regression coefficients between \(Y\) and \(I\) after the removal of the ENSO effect, reflecting the relatively independent association between the climate variable and each ocean index.In this analysis, the NINO3.4 index is removed using its DJF-mean value to account for ENSO’s mature-phase influence and its delayed impacts on subsequent seasons. In subsequent regressions, the Pacific (CEP) index is represented by its DJF value to reflect the dominant wintertime ENSO forcing, while TIO and TNA indices are used in their concurrent seasons based on their seasonally confined influence (Supplementary Fig. 4d–f).

Data availability
              
              The CMIP6 dataset is accessible via the ESGF portal at https://esgf-data.dkrz.de/search/cmip6-dkrz/. The NOAA ERSST-v5 dataset can be obtained from https://downloads.psl.noaa.gov/Datasets/noaa.ersst.v5/. ERA5 reanalysis data are available at https://doi.org/10.24381/cds.f17050d7. All data supporting the findings of this study are provided within the article and its supplementary materials.
