items.title: Seasonal variations of tropical cyclone genesis and landfall patterns impacting Southeast Asia in a warmer climate
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 03 November 2025

Seasonal variations of tropical cyclone genesis and landfall patterns impacting Southeast Asia in a warmer climate
                    Mackenzie M. Weaver 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-2177-22801,2, Andra J. Garner 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-4994-92712, Dhrubajyoti Samanta 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-7477-55843, Michael E. Mann 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-3067-296X1 & …Benjamin P. Horton 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-9245-37684 Show authors

Communications Earth & Environment

volume 6, Article number: 866 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Natural hazardsProjection and prediction

AbstractEvolving tropical cyclone characteristics are expected to amplify coastal hazards in a warmer climate. Here, we investigated seasonal-scale tropical cyclone genesis and landfall patterns from >64,000 statistically-downscaled tropical cyclones that impact Southeast Asian coastlines from the historical (1881–1900) through the future (2081–2100) eras for both moderate and high emission scenarios. From the historical to future eras, tropical cyclone genesis shifts northwards across seasons, with an increased likelihood of genesis adjacent to major coastlines. Proportional increases in genesis exceed 100% during the winter monsoon season and up to 50% during the summer monsoon season. Relative humidity and vertical wind shear become increasingly important influences on tropical cyclone genesis, particularly during the summer monsoon and autumn seasons. There are also increased likelihoods of tropical cyclones making their first landfall along the coastlines of the Philippines and Indonesia during the winter monsoon and spring seasons, and along mainland Southeast Asian coastlines during the summer monsoon and autumn seasons. These changes demonstrate the need for improved coastal resiliency and mitigation strategies in this highly populated part of the world.

IntroductionTropical cyclones (TCs) pose a risk to Southeast Asia1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8. TCs generate destructive winds, heavy rainfall, and intense storm surges that can be extremely damaging to coastal communities1,2,3,9, with many storms costing the equivalent of billions of USD in damages10,11,12,13 and causing thousands of casualties3,10,11.A variety of studies have found significant changes to TC genesis and landfall patterns in Southeast Asia during the observational period, including a shift towards genesis near densely populated coastlines14, a northward shift in landfall patterns15, and correlations between the frequency of western North Pacific TC genesis and the East Asian summer monsoon phase16,17. However, there are very few long-term studies that examine how seasonal-scale variations in TC behavior may evolve in a warming climate18,19. Here, we investigated long-term changes to seasonal patterns of TC genesis and subsequent first landfall locations along Southeast Asian coastlines. We analyzed changes in genesis patterns in six different regions, four separate eras, and four distinct seasons based on monsoonal variability (Table 1, Fig. S1). We found spatial and temporal TC genesis shifts from the historical era to both a moderate (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway [SSP] 2-4.520) and high emissions (SSP5-8.520) future that have critical impacts on where TCs make landfall along Southeast Asian coastlines.Table 1 Regions and eras of focus for analysesFull size tableResultsWe evaluated changes to the genesis and landfall patterns of TCs that impact Southeast Asia from a historical era (1881–1900) to a modern era (1981–2000) and a future era (2081–2100) for both moderate (SSP 2-4.520) and high emissions (SSP5-8.520). To assess seasonal variations in TC genesis and landfall changes, we considered four distinct seasons throughout the year: the winter monsoon season (December through February); the spring season (March through May); the summer monsoon season (June through September); and the autumn season (October and November). To compare regional shifts, we assessed TC genesis changes in six individual regions: the Bay of Bengal, South China Sea, northern North Pacific, southern North Pacific, northern Australia, and western Australia (Table 1, Fig. S1). Finally, we used a principal component analysis to evaluate the changes to genesis and landfall patterns within the context of large-scale climate variables in our datasets, such as 600-hPa relative humidity, 850–250 hPa vertical wind shear, central surface pressure, and 600 hPa air temperature (see Supplementary Methods).Winter monsoon seasonWinter monsoon TC genesis increased across all northern hemisphere focus regions from the historical era to the future era, regardless of emission scenario (Figs. 1a, b, 2a–d, S1, S2a–d). Under a high-emissions future, these increases were significant in the South China Sea, northern North Pacific, and southern North Pacific (90% credible interval (CI); Figs. 2b–d, 3a,  S2b–d). The largest relative increases in total genesis occurred in the southern North Pacific, with genesis increasing from 16.8% in the historical era to 28.1% in a high-emissions future (Figs. 2d, 3a, S2d; Table 2). Proportionally, the largest relative increase in winter monsoon season genesis occurred in the South China Sea, where genesis increased by 288.3% in a high-emissions future relative to the historical era (Fig. 4a). There are also proportional increases of >100% in winter monsoon season genesis in the Bay of Bengal and northern North Pacific from the historical era to both future eras (Fig. 4a).Fig. 1: Density difference maps of TC genesis locations during different parts of the year.Density differences are shown for the SSP2-4.5 future era minus the historical era (a, c, e, g) and the SSP5-8.5 future era minus the historical era (b, d, f, h) during the winter monsoon season (a, b), the spring season (c, d), the summer monsoon season (e, f), and the autumn season (g, h). Solid rectangles designate the Bay of Bengal region, dashed/dotted rectangles designate the South China Sea region, dotted rectangles designate the northern North Pacific region, dashed rectangles designate the southern North Pacific region, long-dashed rectangles designate the northern Australia region, and double-dashed rectangles designate the western Australia region. Hatching indicates agreement between at least six of the nine models in the ensemble. Note that to clearly show all results, colorbars are uniform within each season (rows) but differ across seasons (columns). A scale factor of 1000 has been applied to all colorbar values. Units for the colorbars are TC points per grid cell, where each map has 100 grid cells in both the latitudinal and longitudinal directions.Full size imageFig. 2: Changing probability of genesis across eras in Northern Hemisphere regions.Genesis probabilities are shown for the Bay of Bengal (BOB; a, e, i, m), South China Sea (SCS; b, f, j, n), northern North Pacific (NNP; c, g, k, o), and southern North Pacific (SNP; d, h, l, p). Plots illustrate genesis across eras for each region during the winter monsoon season (a–d), spring season (d–h), summer monsoon season (i–l), and autumn season (m–p). Genesis probabilities are shown for the historical era (light blue), modern era (dark blue), moderate-emissions future (light pink), and high-emissions future (dark pink). Error bars show bootstrapped 90% credible intervals.Full size imageFig. 3: Bar graphs displaying the amount of TC genesis in each region across eras.Genesis amounts are shown for the historical (light blue), modern (dark blue), SSP2-4.5 future (light pink), and SSP5-8.5 future (dark pink) eras. Bars show changing amounts of TC genesis across eras during a the winter monsoon season, b the spring season, c the summer monsoon season, and d the autumn season. Each panel shows changing genesis amounts in the Bay of Bengal (BOB), South China Sea (SCS), northern North Pacific (NNP), southern North Pacific (SNP), northern Australia (NAUS), and western Australia (WAUS). Error bars show bootstrapped 90% credible intervals.Full size imageFig. 4: Bar graphs displaying the proportional change in TC genesis.Proportional changes are shown for the historical to modern era (yellow), the historical to SSP2-4.5 future era (orange), and the historical to SSP5-8.5 future era (purple) for a the winter monsoon season, b the spring season, c the summer monsoon season, and d the autumn season. Bars are grouped into regions of focus shown on the x-axis: the Bay of Bengal (BOB), South China Sea (SCS), northern North Pacific (NNP), southern North Pacific (SNP), northern Australia (NAUS), and western Australia (WAUS).Full size imageTable 2 Percentages of TC genesis throughout parts of the season, regions, and erasFull size tableWinter monsoon TC genesis exhibited relative decreases in both southern hemisphere focus regions from the historical era to the future era, regardless of emission scenario, with significant decreases in the western Australia region (90% CI; Figs. 1a, b, 3a, 5a, b, S3a, b). Despite these relative decreases from 42% in the historical era to 35% in a high-emissions future, winter monsoon season TC genesis was most prevalent in western Australia across all eras (Figs. 3a, 5b, S3b; Table 2). The greatest proportional decrease in winter monsoon genesis occurred in the northern Australia region, where genesis declined by 20% from the historical era to a moderate-emissions future (Fig. 4a).Fig. 5: Changing probability of genesis across eras in Southern Hemisphere regions.Genesis probabilities are shown for northern Australia (NAUS; a, c, e, g) and western Australia (WAUS; b, d, f, h). Plots illustrate genesis across eras for each region during the winter monsoon season (a and b), spring season (c and d), summer monsoon season (e and f), and autumn season (g and h). Genesis probabilities are shown for the historical era (light blue), modern era (dark blue), moderate-emissions future (light pink), and high-emissions future (dark pink). Error bars show bootstrapped 90% credible intervals.Full size imageAir temperature was the primary influence on changing genesis patterns during the winter monsoon season. Its impact became stronger from the historical to future era, suggesting that increasing air temperatures were among the most critical factors for increasing TC genesis in the northern hemisphere during winter (Fig. S4).Spring seasonSpring genesis increased in all Pacific-basin focus regions (Table 1) from the historical era to the future era, regardless of emission scenario (Figs. 1c, d, 2f–h, 5c, S2f–h, S3c), though these increases were not significant using a 90% CI (Figs. 2f–h, 3b, 5c, S2f–h, S3c). During the spring season, the greatest proportional increase occurred in the South China Sea from the historical to high-emissions future era, with genesis in this region increasing by 22% over this period (Fig. 4b).Spring genesis declined in Indian basin regions (Table 1), where significant relative decreases occurred in the western Australia region from the historical era to the future era, regardless of emission scenario (90% CI, Figs. 2e, 3b, 5d, S2e, S3d). It is worth noting that these decreases were relative changes, and that, despite decreased rates of genesis in western Australia from the historical (18%) to both the moderate emissions (15%) and high emissions (14%) future eras (Figs. 2e, 3b, 5d, S2e, S3d; Table 2), overall genesis rates in western Australia and the Bay of Bengal were comparatively high in all eras compared to most other regions. The greatest proportional decrease in spring season genesis occurred in the western Australia region, with a decline of 20% from the historical era to the moderate emissions future and 22% from the historical era to the high emissions future (Fig. 4b).Among the large-scale environmental variables, central surface pressure was most influential on genesis patterns during all eras during spring (Fig. S4). However, the exact nature of this relationship was unclear and varied by era. In the historical era, genesis and pressure were positively correlated, and this positive correlation persisted in the moderate-emissions future (Fig. S4e, g). In a high-emissions future, however, the correlation became negative (Fig. S4h). Collectively, this varying relationship indicated that evolving background surface pressures throughout the domain were related to the increased genesis observed in certain regions over this period (Fig. S4).Summer monsoon seasonFrom the historical era to both the moderate and high emissions future eras, summer monsoon season genesis shifted northwestward and became more concentrated in the Bay of Bengal and the South China Sea. Genesis increases in these two regions were significant from the historical to future era, regardless of the emission scenario (90% CI; Figs. 1e, f, 2I, j, 3c, S2i, j). Overall, very little genesis occurred in the northern and western Australia regions during the summer monsoon season (<0.5% in each region during all eras), but there were also moderate (though not statistically significant) relative increases in these regions over the same periods (Fig. 1e, f; 5e, f, S3e, f). The greatest relative and proportional increases in summer monsoon season genesis occurred in the Bay of Bengal, where genesis increased from 6% in the historical era to 9% in the high-emissions future era—a 51% proportional increase (Figs. 2i, 3c, 4c, S2i; Table 2).Coinciding with increased genesis in the Bay of Bengal and the South China Sea, summer monsoon season genesis declined in the northern and southern North Pacific from the historical to the future era, regardless of the emission scenario. These relative decreases were significant from the historical to moderate emissions future era (90% CI; Figs. 2k, l, 3c, S2k, l). The greatest relative and proportional decreases occurred in the southern North Pacific, where genesis decreased from 25% in the historical era to 18% in the high emissions future era—a 26% proportional decrease (Figs. 2l, 3c, 4c, S2l; Table 2).During the summer monsoon season, air temperature was a consistent influence on genesis patterns across eras, as is expected in a warming climate21,22. However, both relative humidity and vertical wind shear also seemed to impact TC genesis during this season from the historical to the future era. Relative humidity was particularly impactful, with increases across the domain appearing to influence the northwestward shift in genesis locations (Fig. S5).Autumn seasonAutumn genesis became more concentrated in the Bay of Bengal, South China Sea, and northern North Pacific from the historical era to the future era, regardless of the emission scenario (Fig. 1g, h). Genesis increases in these three regions were significant from the historical to high-emissions future era (90% CI; Figs. 2m–o, 3d, S2m–o). The greatest relative increase occurred in the northern North Pacific, where genesis increased from 31% in the historical era to 37% in the high-emissions future (Figs. 2o, 3d, S2o; Table 2). The greatest proportional increase in autumn genesis occurred in the Bay of Bengal from the historical to high emissions future, where the proportion of autumn genesis in this region increased by 40% over this period (Fig. 4d).The above genesis increases in the Bay of Bengal, South China Sea, and northern North Pacific genesis were accompanied by decreases in the southern North Pacific, northern Australia, and western Australia from the historical to high emissions future era (Fig. 1g, h). Among these, decreases were significant in the southern North Pacific but not in the northern and western Australia regions for any era (90% CI; Figs. 2p, 3d, 5g, h, S2p, S3g, h). The greatest relative decrease occurred in the southern North Pacific, where genesis declined from 42% in the historical era to 32% in the high-emissions future, indicating a northward shift in North Pacific genesis during the autumn season (Figs. 2p, 3d, S2p; Table 2). The greatest proportional genesis decrease occurred in the Western Australia region from both the historical to moderate emissions future (decrease of 33%) and the historical to high emissions future (decrease of 23%; Fig. 4d).Similarly to the summer monsoon season, air temperature was a consistent influencer of autumn genesis patterns across eras, but both relative humidity and vertical wind shear appeared to have increasingly important impacts on TC genesis during autumn from the historical to future era (Fig. S5). Changes in vertical wind shear throughout the domain were positively correlated with autumn genesis, suggesting that changing vertical wind shear in the domain influenced the northward genesis shift during the autumn season.Seasonal changes to tropical cyclone genesis distributionSpatial variations in seasonal TC genesis coincided with varying temporal distributions of genesis throughout the year across all regions. Changes in the seasonal distributions of genesis for all six focus regions were described from the historical to future eras as a shift from the spring season towards the later seasons of the year (i.e. the summer monsoon season, autumn season, and occasionally portions of the winter monsoon season).In the Bay of Bengal, genesis became less likely during the spring and more likely during both the summer monsoon and autumn seasons (Fig. 6a; Table 3). Similarly, northern Australia and western Australia genesis declined during the spring season and increased during the autumn season (Fig. 6b, c; Table 3). The southern hemisphere regions also experienced substantial shifts during the winter monsoon season that were absent in the northern hemisphere regions. Specifically, genesis increased in northern Australia during the winter monsoon season from the historical to future era, whereas genesis declined in western Australia during this season over the same period (Figs. 6b, c, S6, S7; Table 3).Fig. 6: Point plots displaying the temporal distribution of genesis within each region across eras.Genesis proportions are shown for the historical (light blue), modern (dark blue), SSP2-4.5 future (light pink), and SSP5-8.5 future (dark pink) eras. Temporal distributions are shown for a Bay of Bengal genesis, b northern Australia genesis, c western Australia genesis, d South China Sea genesis, e northern North Pacific genesis, and f southern North Pacific genesis. Gray dashed lines indicate the beginning of each season.Full size imageTable 3 Percentages of TC genesis within each region across parts of the season and erasFull size tableIn the North Pacific (the South China Sea, northern North Pacific, and southern North Pacific), there were decreases in the likelihood of genesis occurring during the summer monsoon season in addition to the springtime genesis declines. In these areas, genesis still moves towards later seasons of the year, with increases during the autumn season (Fig. 6d–f). Although winter monsoon season genesis remains minimal in these regions (less than 1% of genesis within each region occurs during the winter monsoon season across eras), there were small increases in genesis during portions of this season for North Pacific regions as well (Figs. 6d–f, S6, S7; Table 3).Impacts upon tropical cyclone landfall locationsChanges in TC genesis were accompanied by shifts in the locations where TCs first made landfall across Southeast Asia.During the winter monsoon season, the frequency of first TC landfalls increased from the historical to both the moderate and high emissions future eras in the Philippines and along the southern coastlines of the Indonesian islands Kalimantan and Sulawesi (Fig. 7a, b). In contrast, landfalls decreased in frequency along the northern Australian coast, the Indonesian island of Java, and southern coastlines of both the Indonesian island of Sumatra and Papua New Guinea over the same period. Southern hemisphere TCs that travel near Southeast Asia during their lifetimes also became less likely to make landfall in Madagascar (Fig. 7a, b).Fig. 7: Density difference maps of TC landfall locations.Maps show the density differences for the SSP2-4.5 future era minus the historical era (a, c, e, g) and the SSP5-8.5 future era minus the historical era (b, d, f, h) during the winter monsoon season (a, b), the spring season (c, d), the summer monsoon season (e, f), and the autumn season (g, h). Hatching indicates agreement between at least six of the nine models in the ensemble. Note that to clearly show all results, colorbars are uniform within each season (rows) but differ across seasons (columns). A scale factor of 1000 has been applied to all colorbar values. Units for the colorbars are TC points per grid cell, where each map has 100 grid cells in both the latitudinal and longitudinal directions.Full size imageDuring the spring season, initial TC landfalls increased from the historical to moderate emissions future era along the coasts of Vietnam, Cambodia, the Philippines, much of Indonesia, and southwest Australia. Over the same period, first landfalls decreased along much of the Chinese, Japanese, and southeastern Russian coastlines, as well as in Papua New Guinea, northeastern Australia, and along coastlines bordering the Bay of Bengal. Spring TC landfalls also changed over time in regions where historically, landfalls have been relatively rare—including increases along the coastlines of northeastern Russia and decreases in Madagascar (Fig. 7c). Spring season landfall trends from the historical era to a moderate emissions future were generally consistent with trends over the same period for a high emissions future, with a few exceptions. In a high emissions future, initial TC landfalls increased rather than decreased in northern Japan, northwestern Australia, Papua New Guinea, and eastern Indonesia. The decreases in landfalls along the Bay of Bengal coastlines extended further east to include coastlines along Thailand, Cambodia, Laos, and Vietnam in the high emissions future (Fig. 7d).During the summer monsoon season, landfalls increased along the coastlines of Myanmar, Bangladesh, portions of Thailand, southern China, and northeastern Russia from the historical to the moderate emissions future era. Over the same period, landfalls decreased in Vietnam, Philippines, the Korean Peninsula, and Japan (Fig. 7e). These trends remained mostly consistent between the moderate and high emissions futures, with a couple of exceptions; under a high-emissions future, landfalls increased along most Japanese coastlines and decreased in much of southern China (Fig. 7f).During the autumn season, the first TC landfalls increased from the historical era to both the moderate and high emissions future eras along coastlines bordering the Bay of Bengal, western Philippines, Cambodia, Vietnam, and southern China. Conversely, over the same period, landfalls decreased in the rest of the Philippines, southern Thailand and Malaysia, eastern China, and southern Japan (Fig. 7g, h).DiscussionTC characteristics may vary in a warmer climate, causing changes to the hazards these storms pose to Southeast Asian coastal communities. Previous work has shown that these impacts could include variations in intensification rates14,19,23 as TCs approach Southeast Asian coastlines and increased TC-related rainfall24,25,26. Other studies suggested that western North Pacific TCs may also persist for longer durations and penetrate farther inland in a warmer future1,19. Here, this long-term study supplements these previous findings by filling knowledge gaps about how TC genesis climatology for Southeast Asian coastlines may vary under different emission scenarios, and how these changes may impact the locations at which TCs make their first landfall.Genesis shifts vary widely depending on both the time of year and the emission scenario considered. Broadly, during the winter monsoon season, genesis increased in all northern hemisphere regions from the historical era to the future. Spring season genesis patterns show genesis increased in all Pacific basin regions and decreased in all Indian Ocean basin regions from the historical era to the future (Table 1, Figs. 1–5, S2, S3). Regional variations in genesis patterns during the summer monsoon and autumn seasons can generally be described as a northwestern shift in the location of TC genesis from the historical to the future era (Figs. 1–5, S2, S3), with a particularly noticeable poleward shift in genesis across the northern and southern North Pacific27,28,29,30,31,32. Our results suggest the potential for more TCs to form closer to densely populated Southeast Asian coastlines in a warmer future, particularly during the summer monsoon and autumn seasons.Unsurprisingly, throughout the year, the greatest proportional changes in TC genesis occurred in regions that see relatively less overall genesis during each season. For example, the Bay of Bengal and South China Sea tended to see less overall genesis than the northern or southern North Pacific during the winter monsoon, summer monsoon, and autumn seasons; however, proportional increases (often above 100%) were exceptionally large for these areas as TC formation became more common in these locations over time, but remained relatively rare (Fig. 4). Similarly, the northern and western Australia regions had minimal genesis during the summer monsoon and autumn seasons compared with other regions, resulting in relatively large proportional increases during summer monsoon and decreases during autumn (Fig. 4). These remarkable proportional changes in locations and seasons where TC formation has historically been relatively uncommon emphasize that genesis variations at these times and locations may produce outsize impacts for adjacent coastal communities.Genesis shifts across emission scenarios were consistent within each region and season, with the high emissions scenario showing a stronger signal compared to the moderate emissions. However, there were some instances where the moderate-emissions signal was stronger, such as the decreased northern North Pacific genesis during the summer monsoon season (Fig. 4c). One potential explanation for this is the effect of differing aerosol concentrations between the two emission scenarios on TC characteristics. Previous work determined that aerosols and higher greenhouse gas concentrations were likely to have contrasting effects on TC behavior, particularly in terms of TC intensity33,34,35,36. It is plausible that the higher concentrations of aerosols in a high-emissions future may counteract some of the effects of increased emissions upon TC genesis patterns, which may help explain some of the inconsistency across emission scenarios within our results.While regional shifts in genesis were significant using a 90% CI during most seasons from the historical to high emissions future era, shifts in spring genesis were not significant in any region except western Australia (Figs. 2, 3, 5, S2, S3). This is expected, as the spring season falls at the beginning of the northern hemisphere TC season37, when TC activity may be limited. In our Pacific focus regions, <10% of genesis in each region occurred during the spring season in all eras (Table 3, Fig. S1). In addition, previous works suggested changes to summer monsoon timing and air–sea coupling in a warmer climate that may reduce TC activity near Southeast Asia during the spring season38,39,40. However, highly varied interactions of various TC seasons and monsoons make it difficult to succinctly characterize any single effect of monsoonal changes in a changing climate16,18,39,41,42.In addition to changing spatial patterns of genesis, the temporal distribution of genesis throughout the year also varied from the historical era to the future. All regions have reduced genesis during the spring season and increased genesis during the summer monsoon season, the autumn season, and/or portions of the winter monsoon season (Fig. 6). Collectively, these variations suggest that in a warmer climate, TCs will pose the greatest threat to Southeast Asian coastal communities during the latter half of the year, particularly from July through December, spanning most of the summer monsoon months, and extending through the early winter monsoon season.An analysis of large-scale environmental variables indicated that the primary environmental influences on the genesis shifts identified here considerably depend on the era and season. This analysis suggests that while air temperature and central surface air pressure were the most prominent influences on TC genesis during the winter monsoon and spring seasons, respectively, changes in relative humidity and vertical wind shear will be increasingly important factors in future TC genesis patterns during the summer monsoon and autumn seasons (Figs. S4, S5). However, the complexity of these results also indicates a need for further detailed work investigating these environmental variables and their impact on TC variations, particularly as they may relate to future monsoonal variability at different times of the year.In addition to large-scale atmospheric variables, it is plausible that other environmental factors also played a role in changing genesis patterns. For example, the global rise in sea surface temperature that has already been observed and is expected to be amplified in a warmer future43 may impact when and where TCs are most likely to form. The rising sea surface temperatures in the Indo-Pacific warm pool may have a particularly notable impact on TC activity near Southeast Asia14,22,44,45,46,47,48,49. In addition, an expansion of the Hadley cell has been identified as a potential driver of both past and future poleward shifts in TC genesis and landfall locations27,28,29,32,50,51. The Indian Ocean Dipole is another important factor influencing TC genesis in the Bay of Bengal and western North Pacific52,53,54, but its response to anthropogenic climate change remains highly uncertain55,56,57. The El Niño Southern Oscillation also heavily affects TC activity in Southeast Asia15,58,59. There is extensive literature on the current relationship between El Niño Southern Oscillation and Southeast Asia TCs under modern climate conditions60,61,62,63, but the effect of anthropogenic climate change on El Niño Southern Oscillation characteristics is largely uncertain. Therefore, El Niño Southern Oscillation’s potential influence on TC genesis patterns in this region in a warmer future is unclear. Furthermore, many Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 6 (CMIP6) models show a bias towards an El Niño-like mean state, suggesting that TC genesis may be underestimated in our results, particularly in our North Pacific and southern hemisphere regions64,65,66,67,68. These numerous complex interactions highlight the need for future research focused on identifying and isolating the environmental drivers of long-term TC genesis changes near Southeast Asia.Despite uncertainty in the driving factors behind TC genesis changes, variations in where future TCs form in a warmer climate have critical impacts on where they make their initial landfall. Similar to genesis trends, the locations where future TCs made their first landfall varied widely depending on both the season and the emission scenario. TC landfalls during the winter monsoon season shifted northward and became more concentrated in the Philippines and northern Indonesia in the future (Fig. 7a, b). Spring and summer monsoon season landfall shifts were more variable across emission scenarios, but future landfalls became more likely in Indonesia and less likely along most of mainland Southeast and East Asia during the spring season, and more likely in the Philippines during the summer monsoon season (Fig. 7c–f). During the autumn season, future TCs became more likely to make landfall along coastlines bordering the Bay of Bengal and the South China Sea and less likely to make landfall in Japan (Fig. 7g, h). Notably, first TC landfalls also varied where such events have historically been rare, such as in equatorial areas69, high latitudes70, and along Japanese coastlines during the spring season71 (Fig. S8). Though these events remained relatively rare in a warmer future (for instance, only 1.5% of high emissions future TCs made landfall within 5° latitude of the equator and only 4.2% made landfall north of 50°), even the slight changes seen in our results are statistically significant using our threshold of six out of nine models agreeing on the change (see the “Methods” section). This may cause such locations to feel the effects of TC landfall changes more acutely72, given their historical rarity.Here, we focused on relative changes in TC genesis and landfall across different emissions scenarios. Absolute frequency changes are well-studied in the TC literature43, including studies assessing absolute frequency changes in the Indian and Pacific basins73,74,75. Though not the focus of our current study, future studies with our selected models could add value to the established literature by examining absolute frequency changes under various scenarios.To contextualize the TC genesis and landfall changes identified here, we validated our downscaled TCs (which have large numbers of simulated storms, but can be expected to contain inherent model biases) against the best tracks observational record76,77 (which reflects the true genesis pattern, but offers a dataset that is much sparser; Figs. S9–S17). Although the downscaled TCs exhibit a poleward bias relative to TC genesis locations in the best tracks dataset, the overall spatial patterns and probabilities of TC genesis and landfall are similar between the two datasets (Figs. S9, S10, S12, S13). Some quantitative differences between the downscaled TCs and the best tracks TCs are expected due to the limited observational record compared to the thousands of synthetic TCs in our downscaled datasets. These differences are consistent with previous studies that found biases in both TC genesis locations and the environmental factors influencing TC formation near SE Asia, including in several of the CMIP6 models used to generate our downscaled datasets78,79,80 (see the “Methods” section). Nonetheless, the qualitative agreements demonstrate that the downscaled datasets based on CMIP6 models used here can reasonably capture TC genesis variations in Southeast Asia. At the same time, the biases revealed by this analysis emphasize a continued need for improving model accuracy when it comes to representing observed TC genesis patterns78,79,80,81,82.The seasonal shifts in TC genesis and landfall identified in our results demonstrate the complex and evolving nature of the TC hazard to Southeast Asian coastal communities. Southeast Asia is amongst the most densely populated regions on the planet, with a current population of almost 700 million people83, the majority of whom live in coastal regions84, and includes three coastal megacities with populations of at least 10 million people as of 2018 (Jakarta, Indonesia; Manila, Philippines; Bangkok, Thailand)85,86,87,88. The crowded coastlines of Southeast Asia are particularly vulnerable to TC impacts, including TC-associated storm surges and inland flooding from TC rainfall events89,90, both hazards that are amplified by the rapid subsidence that many Southeast Asian coastal cities are experiencing due to excessive groundwater extraction91. Outside of urban population centers, flooding from TCs also threatens the health of coastal ecosystems, soil fertility and crop yields in agricultural fields, and drinking water supplies92,93. Our results demonstrate seasonal-scale shifts in TC genesis in a warmer climate that impact the TC hazard facing Southeast Asia. These changing hazards may be further compounded by other evolving TC characteristics, such as slower forward storm motion or a tendency for TCs to travel further inland before dissipating in a warmer future1,8,19,94. The existing vulnerabilities of Southeast Asian coastal communities demonstrate a growing need not only for an improved understanding of evolving TC characteristics and climatology in a warmer climate, but also for extensive planning to improve both coastal resiliency and mitigation strategies that will serve to protect Southeast Asian coastal communities from future TC impacts.MethodsSynthetic tropical cyclonesTo conduct a broad, long-term evaluation of past, present, and future TC characteristics, we use synthetic TCs downscaled from nine Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 6 (CMIP6) global climate models. Large numbers of synthetic TCs are generated using the statistical/deterministic model described in previous studies95,96,97. This model uses both thermodynamic and kinematic state variables from CMIP6 models98 to produce 16,200 TCs for each era we consider, for a total of more than 64,000 synthetic TCs. This approach creates synthetic TCs under a range of plausible past, present, and future climate scenarios to assess both past changes in TC genesis and landfall behavior and how these TC characteristics may further evolve in a warming climate. This method is well-documented in the TC literature and has been widely used in the scientific community over the past two decades to investigate various TC characteristics in different climate scenarios2,19,99,100,101,102,103. Validation analyses for the TC simulations from this model have been conducted for the CMIP6 suite of models as recently as 2021104, lending confidence to our use of this method to conduct a robust analysis of TC genesis and landfall variations in a warming climate.The nine CMIP6 models used to generate TCs for this work include CanESM5.0.3 (Canadian Earth System Model version 5)105, CESM2 (Community Earth System Model version 2)106, CNRM-CM6-1 (Centre National de Recherches Meteorologiques and Cerfacs version 6-1)107, EC-Earth3108, HadGEM3 (Hadley Centre Global Environment Model version 3)109, IPSL-CM6A-LR (Institut Pierre-Simon Laplace Climate Model version 6)110, MIROC6 (the Sixth Version of the Model for Interdisciplinary Research on Climate)111, MPI-ESM1.2 (Max Planck Institute for Meteorology Earth System Model)112, and UKESM1 (United Kingdom Earth System Model version 1)113. These models represent a reasonably large ensemble of CMIP6 simulations and contain all the necessary fields for us to perform a seasonal-scale analysis of long-term TC genesis and landfall variations, providing historical context for both modern and future (SSP2-4.5 and SSP-8.520) changes. Results for each model are represented by different colors in Figs. S2 and S3, as defined in the Fig. S2 caption and figure legends.Synthetic TCs are produced using a random seeding process96, where warm-core vortices with peak wind speeds of 12 m/s and minimal mid-level humidity anomalies in their cores are randomly placed in all ocean basins relevant for TC impacts on Southeast Asia at all locations poleward of 2˚ latitude during all parts of the year. The majority of these seeds fail to form TCs due to unfavorable environmental conditions such as high wind shear or low potential intensity. However, vortices that evolve to develop winds of at least 21 m/s (40 kts) are considered TCs 96 and are included in our downscaled datasets. The genesis point for these TCs is the first 2-h time step after their seeds’ original placement.A beta-and-advection model is used to simulate TC tracks96, which relies on 850 and 250 hPa wind fields from the CMIP6 models. First landfall points are determined by interpolating the 2-hourly track points to 15-min time steps and finding the first point at which a TC crosses a coastal national boundary.TCs used in this work are filtered to travel either partially or entirely within a bounding box around Southeast Asia that extends from 10°S to 25°N and from 90°E to 140°E (Fig. S1). Because TCs used here are designed to travel within a defined bounding box around Southeast Asia, these results are not necessarily representative of all TC genesis and landfall patterns in the basins considered, but are extremely relevant for the subset of TCs that impact densely populated Southeast Asian coastlines. Note that many TCs used here form outside the SE Asia bounding box and travel into the domain. Additionally, many of the downscaled TCs that travel through Southeast Asia make landfall elsewhere and thus impact a wide range of other locations, as illustrated in Fig. 7.Our eras of focus are defined as:
                  
                    1.
                    
                      The historical era (1881–1900): historical climate conditions prior to major anthropogenic influence;
                    
                  
                  
                    2.
                    
                      The modern era (1981–2000): recent climate conditions similar to those of the observational era;
                    
                  
                  
                    3.
                    
                      The moderate-emission future (2081–2100; Shared Socioeconomic Pathway (SSP) 2-4.5): a “middle of the road” future climate where modest progress is made toward reducing anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions, resulting in 4.5 W/m2 radiative forcing for the planet by the year 210020,114,115;
                    
                  
                  
                    4.
                    
                      The high-emission future (2081–2100; SSP5-8.5): a “fossil-fueled” future climate where little to no action is taken to curb emissions, resulting in 8.5 W/m2 radiative forcing for the planet by the year 210020,114,115.
                    
                  
                TCs used for this work are also categorized into four distinct seasons, based on monsoonal variability in Southeast Asia. We consider TC changes during the winter monsoon season (December to February), the spring season (an inter-monsoon season spanning from March to May), the summer monsoon season (June to September), and the autumn season (an inter-monsoon season spanning from October to November). For simplicity, the two inter-monsoon seasons are named for the boreal seasons in which they occur.Caveats related to CMIP6 models and the downscaling process used to generate synthetic TCs are discussed at length in other studies95,96,98,104. However, it should particularly be noted that since seeded TC vortices in this downscaling approach have an initial peak wind speed of 12 m/s, any environmental factors that may influence the development of these vortices before this point are not accounted for95,96. Nonetheless, this downscaling method has been shown to capture many aspects of observed TC characteristics and variability well, including the global spatial distribution of genesis and track density95,104.As with any modeling study, it can be expected that additional caveats exist with regard to inherent model biases. A comparison of synthetic TCs modeled for 1981–2000 compared to data from the IBTRACS observational dataset from 1981 to 2000 reveals that TCs downscaled from the CMIP6 model ensemble used here exhibit a poleward bias in spatial distributions of genesis locations relative to IBTrACS best tracks data76,77, resulting in substantial quantitative differences in genesis and landfall probabilities within our six focus regions in the modern era (Figs. S9–S17). This is consistent with previous studies that identify varying biases in how CMIP6 models reflect TC climatology in Southeast Asia, including several models used here78,79,80,81,82. However, despite these quantitative biases, the modeled TCs and the IBTrACS TCs in our analyses reflect similar qualitative patterns in genesis and landfall probabilities, both in their spatial distribution and in the seasonal and regional proportions of genesis events (Figs. S9, S10, S12, S13). Furthermore, six of the nine models we use here have been shown to exhibit biases towards an El Nino-like mean state (CanESM5, CNRM-CM6-1, EC-Earth3, HadGEM3, MIROC6, and MPI-ESM1.2), and one has been shown to exhibit a bias towards a La Nina-like mean state (IPSL-CM6A-LR). Therefore, it should be noted that TC genesis in our results may be under- or over-represented depending on the region considered.Other caveats specific to this study also include the fact that our downscaled datasets contain relatively few storms in certain regions/seasons (e.g., the Bay of Bengal, South China Sea, and northern North Pacific regions during the winter monsoon season and northern Australia and western Australia regions during the summer monsoon and autumn seasons), which provides somewhat limited sample sizes for analyses, introducing uncertainty within our results.Statistics and analysesMaps illustrating spatial variations in TC genesis (Figs. 1 and S9) and first landfall locations (Figs. 7, S8, and S13) were generated using a kernel density estimate for each era and part of the season. The kernel density estimates for the two eras of interest are then subtracted to find the spatial difference over time for the TC genesis/landfall points (Figs. 1, 7, S9c, f, i, S13c, f, i). Density units are provided in terms of genesis/landfall points per grid cell, where each map has 100 grid cells in both the latitudinal and longitudinal directions. This results in a varying resolution for each map, depending on the latitude and longitude bounds, but no resolution is coarser than 1.73° longitude by 1.50° latitude. Additionally, to clearly show the key findings for each era and season, colorbars for Figs. 1 and 7 are uniform within each season, but are different across seasons—a common approach in the scientific literature99,100,103. Significance hatching on these maps indicates that at least six out of our nine models (at least 66%) agree on the sign of the change. Also, we note that the world map used is from the R Worldmap package, and may not represent correct political boundaries for all nations shown, particularly for India.Probabilities of TC genesis for specific regions illustrated in Figs. 2, 3, 5, S2, S3, S10, S11, S14, S15, and S16 and Table 2 are calculated using Eq. (1):$$\frac{{{T}}{{o}}{{t}}{{a}}{{l}}\,{{T}}{{C}}{{s}}\,{{i}}{{n}}\,{{s}}{{p}}{{e}}{{c}}{{i}}{{f}}{{i}}{{c}}\,{{r}}{{e}}{{g}}{{i}}{{o}}{{n}}}{{{T}}{{o}}{{t}}{{a}}{{l}}\,{{T}}{{C}}{{s}}\,{{f}}{{o}}{{r}}\,{{t}}{{h}}{{a}}{{t}}\,{{e}}{{r}}{{a}}\,{{a}}{{n}}{{d}}\,{{s}}{{e}}{{a}}{{s}}{{o}}{{n}}}\times 100{{ \% }}$$
                    (1)
                Essentially, this calculation provides the amount of TC genesis that occurs in each region during a particular season and era. We first determine the total number of TCs generated during a specific part of the season, in a particular region, in each era (e.g. winter monsoon season Bay of Bengal genesis in the historical era), and then divide that value by the total number of TCs in that era and part of the season (e.g. total winter monsoon season genesis during the historical era regardless of the region; Figs. 2, 3, 5, S2, S3, S10, S11, S14, S15, and S16, Table 2).Proportional changes in TC genesis across eras, as illustrated in Fig. 4 are calculated using Eq. (2):$$\frac{{{N}}{{e}}{{w}}\,{{p}}{{e}}{{r}}{{c}}{{e}}{{n}}{{t}}{{a}}{{g}}{{e}}-{{P}}{{r}}{{e}}{{v}}{{i}}{{o}}{{u}}{{s}}\,{{p}}{{e}}{{r}}{{c}}{{e}}{{n}}{{t}}{{a}}{{g}}{{e}}}{{{P}}{{r}}{{e}}{{v}}{{i}}{{o}}{{u}}{{s}}\,{{p}}{{e}}{{r}}{{c}}{{e}}{{n}}{{t}}{{a}}{{g}}{{e}}}\times 100{{ \% }}$$
                    (2)
                This allows us to determine the change in genesis within a particular region relative to itself across eras. We first subtract the previous percentage in a given region and part of the season from the new percentage, then divide this value by the previous percentage (Fig. 4). For example, in the winter monsoon season, the Bay of Bengal genesis in the historical era is 0.20%. To find the proportional change in TC genesis in the Bay of Bengal during the winter monsoon season for a high-emission future, we first subtract this value (0.20%) from the percentage of winter monsoon season Bay of Bengal genesis in the high-emission future (0.41%), and then divide by the original percentage (0.20%). This yields a proportional increase of 104.35% in TC genesis in the Bay of Bengal region in the high-emission future relative to the historical era.We use terminology that refers to differences in percentages to discuss changing amounts of total genesis within a given region relative to all other regions from one era to another, but we use terminology that refers to proportions to compare the change in genesis within a given region relative to itself from one era to another. For example, if one region had 10% of total winter monsoon genesis in the historical era, but 30% of total winter monsoon season genesis in the moderate-emissions future era, we say the percentage of genesis in that region increased by 20% over time. Alternatively, using the same example, we would say the proportion of genesis in that region increased by 200% from the historical to the moderate-emissions future era.Probabilities of TC genesis within each region for a specific season as illustrated in Figs. 6, S12, and S17 and Table 3 are calculated using Eq. (3):$$\frac{{{T}}{{o}}{{t}}{{a}}{{l}}\,{{T}}{{C}}{{s}}\,{{i}}{{n}}\,{{s}}{{p}}{{e}}{{c}}{{i}}{{f}}{{i}}{{c}}\,{{r}}{{e}}{{g}}{{i}}{{o}}{{n}},{{s}}{{e}}{{a}}{{s}}{{o}}{{n}},{{a}}{{n}}{{d}}\,{{e}}{{r}}{{a}}}{{{T}}{{o}}{{t}}{{a}}{{l}}\,{{T}}{{C}}{{s}}\,{{f}}{{o}}{{r}}\,{{t}}{{h}}{{a}}{{t}}\,{{r}}{{e}}{{g}}{{i}}{{o}}{{n}}\,{{a}}{{n}}{{d}}\,{{e}}{{r}}{{a}}}\times 100{{ \% }}$$
                    (3)
                This equation provides the amount of TC genesis within a particular region and era that occurs during each season. We first determine the total number of TCs generated during a specific part of the season, in a particular region, in each era, and then divide that value by the total number of TCs in that region and era (Fig. 6; Table 3).Credible intervals (CIs) are determined by bootstrapping the original data116,117. For Figs. 2, 3, 5, S2, S3, S10, S11, S14, S15, and S16, we generate 5000 bootstrap samples of the TC genesis locations (the Bay of Bengal, South China Sea, northern North Pacific, southern North Pacific, northern Australia, and/or western Australia; Figs. 2, 3, 5, S2, S3, S10, S11, S14, S15, and S16) under consideration to determine the 90% CIs (p = 0.10).Reporting summaryFurther information on research design is available in the Nature Portfolio Reporting Summary linked to this article.

Data availability
              
              This work uses simulated tropical cyclones downscaled from a model developed by Kerry Emanuel (Massachusetts Institute of Technology), and described in Emanuel et al. (2006, 2008, 2021). All inputs to the tropical cyclone model come from CMIP6 datasets that are publicly available from the Earth System Grid Federation website (https://esgf-node.llnl.gov/projects/cmip6/). Downscaled fields from the tropical cyclone model, including storm tracks as defined by TC latitude and longitude at 2-h intervals, are available for research purposes from K. Emanuel (emanuel@mit.edu) on request. Researchers will be asked to sign a non-redistribution agreement and assert that the data will be used for nonprofit research only. Data used in figures for this work are available in DR-NTU (Data) at https://doi.org/10.21979/N9/ICQKAG. Best track data are publicly available at https://www.ncei.noaa.gov/products/international-best-track-archive.
            Code availability
              
              Data analysis for this work was conducted in R & RStudio version 2023.12.1-402. Code is available upon request from M.M.W. (corresponding author).

items.title: Le “regole ambientali” per eventi sostenibili e carbon neutral: la PCR 962
items.description: Eventi a basso impatto climatico E’ stato rilasciato un importante documento che definisce le Regole di Categoria di Prodotto (PCR) per il calco
items.body:
Le “regole ambientali” per eventi sostenibili e carbon neutral: la PCR 962

Approfondimenti

condividi:

Eventi a basso impatto climatico

E' stato rilasciato un importante documento che definisce le Regole di Categoria di Prodotto (PCR) per il calcolo dell'impatto climatico degli eventi ("Carbon Footprint", sinteticamente "CF"), la valutazione primaria per poi attuare soluzioni di riduzione e compensazione delle emissioni di gas serra di un evento pubblico.

In sostanza, la PCR stabilisce cosa considerare nel processo di calcolo della Carbon Footprint degli eventi, che deve essere realizzarsi secondo un approccio tecnico di LCA secondo le indicazioni dello standard ISO 14067.

Le specifiche tecniche che emergono dalla PCR:

Prodotto Coperto: si tratta dell'organizzazione e gestione di eventi di qualsiasi dimensione, portata e durata, organizzati da enti pubblici o Aziende private. La PCR considera eventi sportivi, culturali, sociali, aziendali, networking, fundraising, festival, eventi per la comunità, concerti e spettacoli dal vivo.

Esclusione: sono esclusi gli eventi online.

Codice UN CPC: 962 ("Servizi di spettacolo e altri servizi di intrattenimento dal vivo, presentazione e promozione di eventi").

Unità Funzionale: 1 partecipante (i risultati sono espressi in kgCO2 equivalenti per singola persona).

Durata di Validità: dal 14 febbraio 2023 al 13 febbraio 2028.

Quali dati e quali regole di calcolo sono necessari per il calcolo della CF?

Il CFP segue un approccio "cradle to grave" e si divide in tre fasi: pre-evento, evento e post-evento.

1. Pre-evento (UPSTREAM): comprende progettazione (riunioni), pianificazione e organizzazione (pubblicità e sviluppo). I processi oggetto di valutazione comprendono la produzione di cibo/bevande/gadget, materiali promozionali/comunicazione, strutture temporanee monouso, consumo di energia, alloggio e trasporto per le riunioni organizzative.

2. Evento (CORE): questa fase include le voci di allestimento/preparazione, evento principale, eventi funzionali e intrattenimento collaterale (cibo e bevande). I processi oggetto di valutazione comprendono il trasporto di merci/strutture (solo andata), il trasporto (andata e ritorno) e l'alloggio di staff, partecipanti, accompagnatori e media, consumo di energia e fughe di gas refrigeranti.

3. Post-evento (DOWNSTREAM): si contabilizza il ritorno delle persone e smontaggio dell'evento. I processi oggetto di valutazione comprendono il trasporto di merci/strutture (solo ritorno), smontaggio, consumo di energia per riunioni post-evento significative, e trattamento/trasporto dei rifiuti generati.

Dati Specifici: devono essere quanto più possibile utilizzati i dati primari (raccolti in loco). I dati secondati possono essere usati se non sono disponibili dati specifici, ma devono essere rappresentativi.

Categorie di Impatto (CFP): lo studio è focalizzato sul Potenziale di Riscaldamento Globale (GWP), ovverossia la Carbon Footprint dell'evento.

Il contributo di Rete Clima agli eventi sostenibili e carbon neutral

Attraverso gli eventi le Aziende presentano se stesse, la propria vision, i propri valori, la propria attenzione alla sostenibilità.

Il Protocollo MakEGreen (Make your Event Green) di Rete Clima nasce per limitare l'impronta ambientale degli eventi tramite loro eco-progettazione e per azzerarne l’impatto climatico (carbon neutrality) tramite calcolo e gestione della loro carbon footprint.

Si tratta di un iter integrato rispetto a diversi standard del mondo ISO (quali ISO 20121 + ISO 14067) perchè l'evento sia occasione di concreta azione ambientale e sia strumento di responsabilità, di comunicazione e di "ingaggio green" dei propri stakeholder.

NOTA: i due standard ISO sopraccitati possono essere utilizzati anche singolarmente, Rete Clima propone anche una proposta tecnica basata anche solo sull'uno o sull'altro standard.

Per maggiori informazioni consulta questa pagina web su nostro sito e chiedici informazioni cliccando sul banner a seguito.

Richiedi maggiori informazioni al nostro team

items.title: IKEA insieme a WWF Italia per proteggere l’Orso bruno marsicano
items.description:
IKEA e WWF Italia lanciano una collaborazione per garantire un futuro all'Orso bruno marsicano, simbolo del nostro patrimonio
The post IKEA insieme a
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il leopardo delle Nevi In evidenza Adotta una specie Insieme per salvare un simbolo del patrimonio ambientale italiano. IKEA e WWF Italia lanciano una collaborazione per garantire un futuro all’Orso bruno marsicano. IKEA supporta infatti il progetto del WWF Italia che punta a tutelare questo animale. Dal 1 al 30 novembre 2025, acquistando qualsiasi peluche IKEA, 1 euro sarà destinato al progetto per tutelare questo prezioso simbolo della fauna italiana. Un simbolo in pericolo L’Orso bruno marsicano è una sottospecie endemica dell’Appennino centrale e uno dei simboli del patrimonio ambientale italiano. Questa popolazione è inserita nella lista rossa IUCN tra le specie in pericolo critico di estinzione (si stima la presenza in natura di solo 50-60 esemplari). Tra le principali minacce per la sua sopravvivenza c’è la mortalità causata dall’uomo, sia illegale (bracconaggio tramite arma da fuoco, veleno o trappole), sia accidentale (tramite investimenti stradali in primis). L’uomo ha una grande responsabilità anche nella frammentazione dell’habitat di questo animale. A causarla sono le infrastrutture (strade, ferrovie) che ostacolano i naturali spostamenti degli orsi e aumentano i rischi di mortalità anche in aree idonee. La collaborazione tra IKEA e WWF Italia Per contrastare queste minacce il WWF Italia, grazie alla collaborazione con Ikea, lavora su tre fronti: mettere in sicurezza delle strade, grazie all’installazione di dissuasori visivi e acustici e al ripristino dei sottopassi per garantire passaggi sicuri per l’orso; ridurre i conflitti, grazie alla fornitura di recinzioni elettrificate per proteggere allevamenti e arnie nelle aree di presenza dell’orso; migliorare la percezione sociale dell’orso, grazie ad attività di sensibilizzazione e informazione per comunità locali e turisti che frequentano i territori dell’Appennino centrale.
